location: PRINCESS OF WALES HOSPITAL, EMERGENCY ROOM

text: The doors fly open as a team of EMS WORKERS wheels in a YOUNG PAUL POTTS (9) lying on a gurney. His parents ROLAN and YVONNE POTTS follow. DR. THORPE (29) a new intern meets the team along with a NURSE...
Male, nine years old, possible ruptured eardrum.
His name’s Paul.
Right. Room three, please. He follows the gurney into a triage room, while the nurse waylays Roland and Yvonne with her clipboard.
You’re his parents?
That’s right.
I’‘1l just need to get some basic information from you.
(to his anxious wife) He'll be alright.
(filling in a form) Right, so it’s Paul...last name please?
Potts. P, O, double-T, S.
Paul Potts. Like the Cambodian dictator who massacred all the--?
(for the millionth time...) Not at all like the Cambodian dictator.

Right. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY (FLASHBACK) Shots of the choir... Four rows deep... First and third rows leading the song; rows two and four following severa bars behind... All eyes on the peripatetic CHOIRMASTER... Several rows behind the fourth row, Paul stands alone, singing with gale-force might...
O tidings of comfort and joy, comfort and joy. O tidings of comfort and joy. Several members of the fourth row wince at the decibel level as--
The gurney is locked into position as the medical team takes over. Yvonne wrings her hands in the doorway.
How long since it occurred?
About an bour. They said he just collapsed after his solo.
Miracle he hasn’t ruptured our eardrums from all his hooting and hollering.

(elbowing her husband) He’s a passionate singer. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY (FLASHBACK) Where Paul sways as he solos with eyes fervently shut, hands clenched, voice like a wind throughout the cathedral...
Fear not then said the angel, let nothing you affright. This day is born a Savoir of a pure Virgin bright. To free all those who trust in Him--
--from Satan's power and might. O tidings of comfort and joy. A distinct THUMP is heard... The members of the fourth ro look over their shoulders to find Paul is vanished from sight.
Comfort and joy. O tidings of comfort and Jjoy-
As Paul is wheeled into surgery. Young Dr. Thorpe, now in gown and gloves, meets his parents at the door...
--got some fluid build-up in the middle ear. Not to worry, we'll have him right as rain in no time.
So you've done this sort of thing before?

Of course. Well, not with anyone still breathing... (realizes the faux pas) I’m still new, but rest assured, live or dead, the bits are all the same once you start digging around inside. (now they’re freaked) Cafe’s just down the hall. He heads into surgery... As the doors swing shut--
(arm around his wife) He'll be just fine.

A two-story row house adjoined on either side and identical to the sixty other homes on the block.  The door slams behind Paul, who stands on the landing, carrying his school bag. He pats the large bandage mummifying his repaired ear, then looks both ways before descending the steps to the sidewalk. He checks his surroundings again before venturing out the gate and turning down the road.

There he is! Get ‘im! Paul runs as a flock of screaming YOUNG BOYS crosses the road, hot on his heels... Their screams blend into the continuing choral medley as we return to... INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY Where the same Welsh choir-faces, several years older now continue the song with undiminished fervor over--

Establishing shots of this gray, industrial steel-town huddled on the edge of the Celtic Sea. From above the city, we see Paul, a lone figure running down the center of a road...a moment later the group of boys appears in close pursuit until they catch him and start punching... INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY Reveal that the rows behind the choir are empty... And yet, Paul’s voice rises above the rest, though it sounds impossibly far away...

Paul tears around a corner, the lead pursuers close behin him... He’s slightly older now, closer to thirteen or fourteen with a few extra pounds... He cuts across a busy intersection, narrowly avoiding a lorry which momentarily cuts off his pursuers...

Paul weaves through pedestrians. He’s aged again, nearing eighteen, and puffing even harder with the extra weight. The boys chasing him appear older, larger, and there are more of them than before and they’re gaining on him.

Paul turns down the empty alley, losing his schoolbag to the clutching hand of the closest pursuer... Near the alley’s end, Paul veers wide to the left in anticipation, then cuts right, barely fitting his belly through a narrow pedestrian opening... The lead boys miss the turn, smacking into the alley wall and crumple... INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY Paul’s hidden voice is somewhat louder now as the CAMERA looks down on the choir from above...
Paul looks back to see his lead has widened. He smiles then turns forward an instant too late to avoid the newly constructed scaffolding on the sidewalk... He opens his mouth to scream...

Where Paul lies on the ground, mouth bleeding, bullies standing over him, laughing. MATTHEW, the toughest of the lot, leans forward and allows a stream of spit to dribble onto Paul’s cheek where it mixes with the blood from his ruined mouth.

location: PRINCESS OF WALES HOSPITAL, EMERGENCY ROOM

text: As Paul is brought in on another gurney where he’s met by a slightly aged Dr. Thorpe.
What’ve we got?

Among your friends and kindred that live both far and near. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY CAMERA PULLS OUT of the shattered mouth of PAUL, now in his twenties, singing, with reckless fervor through the shards of two badly broken front teeth...  CAMERA CONTINUES pulling back to reveal he is alone, in the upper choir loft, a good twenty feet above the rest o the choir.
That god send you a happy new year, happy new year. That god send you a happy new year. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY The Choirmaster’s fists clench shut, silencing the choir.
That’s very nice indeed. FADE TO BLACK.
Walls lined with various phones and phone accessories. BRADDON (34), painfully thin with spiky hair, bad skin an elvish ear-extensions, hits on a FEMALE CUSTOMER.
Now this one comes with customizable ringtones and dual vibrating mode, which can come in quite handy in certain situations. The bell jingles as Paul walks in quietly.
And what situations would that be?
(leaning closer) What’ve you got in mind?
I'd like a word with your manager. He shows her his employee badge, that reads “MANAGER” jus below his name, “BRADDON MELLINS”.
What seems to be the problem, Miss?
They should lock you up.
Bondage? Naughty, cheeky, but presto, you talked me into it.  She storms out...
Come see us again soon. ---passing Paul who offers a tentative, closed-mouth smil to Braddon. Hands him
Better luck next time.
It’s quantum algebra, mate; if I offer my personal services to twenty women, one point three of them are certain to shag me blind.
How many have said yes so far?

(calculating) S’about... I’m still tinkering with the approach, but erection is the mother of invention, yes? Right, what can we do ya for? Something compact, ‘round five- hundred minutes a month with unlimited text and a free shaving kit?
Actually, I was wondering if the position’s still open.
The position?
The job.
You want to work here, what in god’s name for?
Because I love mobile phones?
Lying will get you everywhere. an application, then snatches it back...
Have you got a girlfriend?
Yes? Well, sort of-- Not really. Braddon snatches the application back again...
Boyfriend then?
Oh no, she’s definitely a girl, I’m sure of it.
Okay, as long as you’re sure. Paul takes the application and gets to work.

Paul walks home from the interview, passes a pub, The Forge Tavern, from which numerous UNION MEN have spilled out onto the sidewalk. Paul lowers his head and gives the men a wide berth, unti one DRUNK man stumbles into him and “accidentally” drops his beer.
Watch where you’re going, Martha.
Sorry. He tries not to break stride, but the man grabs his arm threateningly...
Sorry ain’t gonna pay for a new pint, is it? Suddenly, the drunk is jerked backwards and ends up on hi ass.
(standing over him) I’‘1l thank you to leave him alone now, Peter.
‘Not my fault he can’t walk straight.
Probably ‘cause his teeth are all crooked.
Or it’s that enormous ass of his.
One more word.
And what?
And your next shift will be in the queue at the unemployment office. Finally, they all back down to his seniority. Roland help the First Drunk to his feet--
Now come on Bill and apologize to-- But Paul is gone.
Paul walks down the center of the road. Roland jogs after him.
All right?
I’m fine, dad.
Pete’s a good lad, he’s just in his cups is all. Paul doesn’t respond. They walk for a moment.
Maybe if you joined a fitness club. Lifted some weights.
Yeah?
I’m just saying... Maybe losin’ a few stone you wouldn’t provoke them as much. Paul looks away; not the first time he’s heard this brand of logic from his father.
I got a job.  10.
What, that bloody musical down the community centre?
Mobile phone shop in Bridgend.
Oh... Well done... So, you’ll be getting your own place then?
Actually, um, I’ve been saving up for opera lessons...in Italy.

You’re twenty-nine years old, Paul. Singing lessons can wait. They turn up the path to their home. Paul hesitates a moment letting Roland go up the steps ahead of him. Furious, he opens his mouth to speak, but loses his nerve... Music is heard - Pavarotti singing “Che Gelida Manina” from La Boeme.

INT. PAUL’S BEDROOM - NIGHT TRACK ACROSS walls plastered with posters and downloaded print-outs of images from the opera world: The Three Tenors; Caruso; a program from La Traviata in Rome; and finally a virtual shrine to Pavarotti, his great hero...

Pointed skyward, quivering slightly in anticipation... Then slicing and waving through the air as Paul angrily “conducts” the music as the refrain kicks in. Gradually, Paul is enveloped and the thrashing needles slow and subside and finally slip to the ground as, panting, he stops the record, revealing a muffled BANGING coming from downstairs.  11.
As Paul makes his way down the stairs and into the kitche where Roland is already at the table.
Always with the bloody violins. Won't shed a tear when they’ve packed and gone.
(serving dinner) What do you mean gone? Paul, are you going somewhere.
Venice.
Oh no, this singing rubbish has gone on long enough. He’s got a job, he can get his own flat.
Pish-posh. (to Paul) Stay forever darling. Here you are. As she places an enormous plate in front of Paul.
Christ, Yvonne, He can hardly fit through the door as it is.

(to Roland) Look, I get it. I’m never going to be a professional singer. I just... It’s the only thing that makes me-- Let me go to Venice and I'll move out when I get back. Yvonne looks at Roland, eyes pleading Paul’s case.
As Paul, gasping and sweating and carrying two moving boxes, climbs several flights up the increasingly narrow staircase until he reaches the top floor and the door to-  12.

Where he drops the boxes alongside several others. The room is partially unpacked with his pictures of Pavarotti and Toscanini already hung with prominence, and his computer has been set up atop a “desk” made from several other boxes. A CHIMING/BOUNCING MESSAGE is seen on the screen... Paul clicks on the message revealing a kitty-kat avatar, which expands into a Chat Invitation from “julzRulz”.
(typed) How did it go? Paul TYPES his response...
How did what go?
Job? Italy? Job? Italy?
Job, yes. Smallest apartment in Britain, yes. Italy, no. How are you?
I’m so sorry, Paul. I guess you'll have to settle for visiting me in Bristol. Hint. Hint. ;) :) A beat as Paul flushes... He types...
I'd love to, but the job starts tomorrow and until I get the cast off my leg, it’s too difficult for me to get around. Paul grimaces at the lie.
(after a beat...) Right.
If I ask you something, promise not to get offended?
Anything?  13.
You are a girl-- (deletes the word girl, replaces it with...) --a woman, right? He sighs with relief at her response and continues “chatting.”
I could feel the firming of her breasts as she pressed them into me.
Where Braddon is in mid-soliloquy as he and Paul stock shelves with bluetooth ear-pieces...
“Be gentle,” said she. “Unicorns are not meant for human love.” “But lady,” said I, “I am only half human.” And I laid her down and took her there, amidst the moss and leaves of the forest floor.
And that was your weekend?
In a nutshell. Yours?
Sorry, but... Did you say you shagged a horse?
It’s a game, role-playing, like Dungeons & Dragons but for real.
So she was a girl, pretending to be a horse.
A unicorn!
Right... Sorry. And you were--?
A half-elf wizard from the Black Mages Guild of Quilanthum.  14.
Right.
When’s the last time you had a bit of fluff?
Em, well...
Right.
She is a girl, by the way. My girlfriend.
When shall we double-date then?
Um, she doesn’t really live here.
Where’s she live, then?
Bristol.
Bristol? That’s miles from-- You have actually met her, haven’t you?
Well, we chat all the time... Shows Braddon his phone-chat which shows a lengthy text- thread between he and julzRulz.
She keeps inviting me up for a visit, but...
But what?
Well, she looks like Cameron Diaz and...
And? Suddenly Paul sees something over Braddon’s shoulder and darts through the curtains into the back of the store.  15.
What’s crawled up his-- He turns to the storefront where Matthew enters belligerently, wearing a blue janitor’s uniform and carrying a smashed cell phone...
The service on this phone is total crap!
It can’t be bad as all that. I can see quarter crap, or maybe even half-- As Matthew dumps the smashed cell phone on the counter.
Right, the thing is, in order for the service to actually work, the phone itself should really be in no more than three or four pieces.
(threatening) It’s under warranty.
Of course, but--

How ‘bout you gimme a phone that works properly and I won’t cram this one down your throat. Yeh? Braddon glances at the cel phone Paul left on the counter then at the curtains at the back of the store.
Excellent.
Paul and Braddon lock up for the night.
Oh, nearly forgot. Flips Paul his phone.
Oh, right. Thanks.  16.
I took the liberty, while you were cowering in the back...
I wasn’t cowering, I was-- Took the liberty to do what?
This Saturday, Swansea Railway Station. She’s on the nine fifteen train. Walks off leaving Paul dumbfounded...
As Paul catches up with Braddon.
What did you do?
It's a bit difficult losing your virginity someone a hundred miles away.
You invited her here?
You did. As far as she knows. And what’s this rubbish about a broken leg?
I told her that so-- She said she looks like Cameron Diaz!
How awful.
It is!
In what universe could that be-- (realizing...) You told her you look like someone famous as well?
A bit, yeah.
Robbie Coltraine? Jack Black? Madonna?  17.
Worse.
Worse than Madonna?
Taped to a mirror-frame in which Paul is seen not coming within a million miles of emulating Pitt’s hair-style. Finally, he gives up and tears the photo from the mirror.

Where Paul waits nervously as the train arrives. He practices several nonchalant leans against a pole before giving up entirely. PASSENGERS flood from the train as the doors open. Paul searches through them, looking for a Cameron Diaz clone. The train pulls away and the crowd thins until Paul is alone on the platform. His heart sinks a little - she stood him up.
Brad? He turns around and has to hide his smile...
Cameron? JULIE-ANNE “JULZ” COOPER, cute but short and thoroughly relieved that she’s not the only one who exaggerated her appearance, smiles back at him. They smile at each other for a moment...
Um, welcome to Port Talbot.

(laughing at him, but ina good way) Thank you. They turn and walk towards the far end of the platform, each taking turns stealing glances at one another.  18. At one point, their hands touch and Paul’s fingers close around hers... The continue walking, neither speaking.
Still holding hands, Paul and Julz walk amidst shoppers.
You’re leg’s much better.
(touching his left leg) Yeah, thanks. Ship-shape. (off her look) What?
I thought it was your right leg?
Oh, right. Um...
Paul, is that you darling?
Oh god. Yvonne appears through the crowd, carrying bags of food from Sainsbury’s and an incredulous look on her face.
Well, bless my soul. Hallo, I’m Paul’s mum. Paul dies a little inside as Julz has to wrest her hand from his to shake Yvonne’s hand.
Lovely to meet you. I’m Julz.
Paul, you didn’t tell me you were... Oh you must come for dinner. My husband would love to--
Thanks, mum, but Julz has to be back to the station by--  19.
(seeing Yvonne's disappointment ) It's alright. I'd love to come. Can we help you with these? She takes several of Yvonne’s bags.
Thank you dear. Aren’t you lovely? Julz looks at Paul. Mouths the word, “Okay?” Paul can’t help but nod and smile/grimace. Julz sticks her tongue ou at him before Yvonne pulls her onwards...
Now then, tell me everything about yourself.
Where the four of them are packed around the small table loaded with food.
--but then I thought to myself, I haven’t got the slightest interest in die-cast aluminum figurines. So I got a job in the pharmacy at Boots.
Good retirement benefits at Boots.
Not so good as Car Phone Warehouse. (to Yvonne) That’s lovely, thanks. Yvonne has piled a towering stack of green-beans on Julz’ plate.
And your parents? What do they do?
Dad.
It’s alright. Mum’s a--  20.
Her mum’s a seamstress and Dad’s on disability from the chemical plant.
Smithsons the one in Bristol?
That’s right. And I hear you’re the foreman down the steel mill? And you, Yvonne, are said to make the best bread pudding in all of Europe.
I am somewhat celebrated for it.
(nudging Paul) Not the only celebrity in the family.
What? Him?
He’s going to be a wonderful singer.
I thought you two only met this morning? Julz takes Paul’s hand under the table.
Nonsense. How could I be his girlfriend if we'd only just met? Paul brightens at this news, as does Yvonne.
They've been chirping on the Internet for quite some time, dear.
It’s not chirping, mum, it’s--
We've been chirping for almost a year.
With all the chirping and singing, it’s no wonder he’s so undeveloped. Paul’s eyes fall to his lap...  21.
You think Paul is undeveloped?!
I wish my mum did all my washing when I was twenty-nine.
I can’t stop her. You just try and stop me! Everyone’s taken aback by Yvonne’s ferocity...
Now then, who’s for a sweet?
Yvonne kisses Julz several times goodbye.
I mean it. Even if Paul’s not here, we can go for a ladies lunch or have our hair done.
Sounds wonderful. Roland appears, palms a packet of condoms into Paul’s hand.
Can’t be too careful. Paul pockets them quickly.
Bye then. Forces his parents inside and pulls the door closed on them. Yvonne is heard yelling at Roland.
Condoms?! Are you out of your bloody mind?!
(to Paul) He didn’t?
Who knows what her intentions are!  22.
(flushed, shows her the condoms ) I’m sorry. I--
What kind of a tart does he think I am?
(to Roland) She’s a lovely girl.
My point exactly. What’s a girl like that want with the likes of him, then?
(sarcastic) She’s after his inheritance! All twenty pounds of it. Hurry, we must hide the Picassos. Julz watches Paul’s face, feeling badly for him.
Dad fell on his head when he was a child. Or last week perhaps.
(re: the condoms) Well, you won’t be needing those, just so’s you don’t have any ideas.

I don’t! I swear. The thought hasn’t even crossed my-- (he’s gone too far) I mean. It has, but... I mean... She puts her finger to her lips. Offers her hand. He take it and they walk off. EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - DAY Paul and Julz sit outside over pints of cider.
He was just mean, really. Shagged my former best friend, then told me it’s because I was getting too-- (eyes reddening) It doesn’t matter.  23.
(taking her hand) He was a tosser.

An enormous tosser. But I’m well past it... I don’t need that much love, I don’t expect it anyway, not coming from where I do. But, nothing ventured, nothing gained as they say... You’ve got to take chances now and again, though it'd be brilliant if it was on something actually worthwhile for change. Paul smiles... He wants to tell her he’s worthwhile, but knows it isn’t something you say... Instead, he traces outlines with his thumb across the back of her hand until
If you could be one person, who would you be?
Well, seeing as I’m a dead ringer for Cameron Diaz... (flutters her eyelashes) Then again, she’s got her own career, famous boyfriends, and an ass I'd sell my mum for. What about you?
I'd be me.
‘Can't be yourself. Have to be someone else.
I don’t want to be someone else.
That confident, are we?
On the contrary. But, if I were someone else, I wouldn’t be here with you.
You’ll get a kiss later for that one... Okay, what if you could meet anyone? Now that I’ve met Brad Pitt, I’1l have to say...Nelson Mandela.  24.
Pavarotti.
He’s your true role model then?
It used to be him and Han Solo, but then I realized Han Solo wasn’t actually real.
Crushing was it?
Horrible scars on my psyche.
He’s Italian? Pavarotti, I mean.
He lives in Monte Carlo now, but he’s on the board of an opera school in Venice.
That's where you want to go, isn’t it?
I’m not good enough to sing professionally, I just like singing for people. It’d be nice to learn properly. Maybe someday.
Would you sing for me? Paul flushes red. Smiles shyly but is clearly uncomfortable...
It’s not that I--
Someday, then?
Someday.
One foot, then the other. Suddenly, the door bursts open and Braddon emerges along with HYDRANGEA, an ethereal looking girl with blonde hair and a unicorn shirt.  25.
What do you mean platonic? How can you be- Hallo Paul. What you doing here? (sees Julz) Is this-- This is! You are!
I am?
She is. (to Hydrangea) And you must be--
Hydrangea.
Right. (re: her shirt) Is that a unicorn? Braddon signals desperately for him to shut up.
Have you signed up for the contest?
Just the cider.
Just as well, I’ve got the blue ribbon in the bag.
What bag is that?
Third annual Halloween costume karaoke competition. Three thousand pound to the winner. Pulls a flyer off the wall, hands it to Paul.
(stunned) Three thousand pound?
Mind you, it’s no amateur night. They get some pretty tough customers in here. (bangs his bird chest) It’s sure be a blood-bath.  26.
You’re a singer, then are you?
(as if it’s obvious...) I’ve got a gorgeous singing voice. (kissing Julz hand) Lovely to meet you. (kisses Paul’s hand) And you. Tries to kiss Hydrangea’s hand, but she flicks him in the forehead.
Come on, Sinatra. You can wash my motor- scooter.
It that code? (off her look) Oh. Right. She drags him away, leaving Julz looking at the embarrassed Paul with raised eyebrows...
Actually, he’s my boss.
You’re joking?

The less you think about him the better. INT. PAUL’S BEDROOM - DAY Only slightly progressed since last time. The boxes are gone and yet it feels even smaller. Julz marvels at the collection of opera posters and flyers.
Wow. I knew you were into opera, but I didn’t know you were completely mad for it.
I’m not fanatical about it or anything. (off her look) Okay, maybe just a little bit. Julz looks at a yellowed, framed newspaper article...  27.
What language is this?
Portuguese. It’s the--
You speak Portuguese?
Not at all. I had it translated though. It's the story of Toscanini’s first performance in 1886... Realizes he’s probably boring her.
Go on. She glances at his knitting needles on the bedside tables... He’s relieved when she doesn’t ask...

He was a cellist in an Italian opera company that was touring South America. (points to the date) One night in 1886, their conductor was booed by the audience and literally forced to leave the podium. In desperation, the singers suggested their assistant Chorus Master take over because he knew the whole opera by heart.
That’s a lot to memorize, is it?
Um, yes it is. And though he had never conducted anything before, Toscanini threw aside the score and led a sensational, two-and-a-half hour performance completely from memory. He was nineteen.
And then he became quite famous, didn’t he? She’s seeing his deepest desires on his sleeve. He realizes he’s gotten carried away.
Sorry.  He smiles 28.
For what? I wish I loved something that much.
There must be something?
Not yet, anyway. as he realizes she means him.
Best get to my train.
Paul and Julz stand side-by-side, still holding hands as her train pulls in, neither wanting the day to end.
I had a lovely day.
I had a lovely day. An awkward beat. Paul has no idea what to do as the train stops.
Sooo, I'll see you when you get back then.
From where?
Venice, of course.
I told you, I’m not going to Italy.

You are. You're going to win that karaoke competition and if the next time we speak you’re not ringing me from a Venetian gondola, I mightn’t think you can sing at all. Then she kisses him, deeply, soundly, with just a bit of tongue.  29.
(gobsmacked) Right.
See ya Brad.

Bye Cameron. Almost without thought, he pulls her to him and kisses he again. Gradually realizing he might have been too forward as evidenced by the shy look on his face as their lips part... The smile that blooms in her mouth and eyes says otherwis as she opens one of the train doors and climbs aboard. He follows her down the train until she finds a seat. He waves and smiles and she closes her eyes and kisses the window between them. The glass steams from her breath and she draws a heart around the imprint of her lipstick. The train pulls away leaving Paul alone but brimming on the platform.

Shots of BUS PASSENGERS staring at something in the back of the bus... Reveal Paul, dressed in a puffy, white clown costume with large neck ruffles, grapefruit-sized pom-poms, a fake beard and white face paint with black, vertical lines bisecting his eyes. He feels the stares and tries to look as if he doesn’t notice them.
Have you gone completely up the pole? EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT Paul looks down at himself, embarrassed.
It's Pavarotti... As Canio... It’s really that bad?
You look like a dead marshmallow.  30.
Oh. So that’s-- What’s you’re costume, then?

head_text.subj: A STACK OF RENTED PA SPEAKERS

text: INT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT The opening beats and squeaks of George Michael’s “I Want Your Sex” blare... Braddon jumps into frame, wearing nothing but a thin pizz box around his waist...

There's things that you guess. And things that you know. There's boys you can trust. And girls that you don't. There's little things you hide. (indicates his groin) And things that you show. (turns, showing everyone his butt) Sometimes you think you're gonna get it. But you don't and that's just the way it goes. The audience is stunned, but some are laughing, and Hydrangea, dressed in shimmery white robes with a tiny nu of horn atop her forehead, sings along to the chorus as Braddon thrusts his pizza box at her.
I swear I won't tease you. Won't tell you no lies. I don't need no bible. Just look in my eyes.
INT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT Braddon does an awkward split as the song ends.

C-c-c-c-c-c-come on! The audience cheers and laughs as he climbs to his feet, trying to hold the pizza box together. Hydrangea hugs him and pulls him into the crowd next to Paul who’s still in shock.  31.
Well done.
Yeah thanks, mate. It’s a gift from-- Kisses his finger then points to heaven... Over by the karaoke equipment, the EMCEE reads from his list.

And now, singing... Blimey... (squints) Vesti la goober. The vocal stylings of Paul Poots. Braddon and Hydrangea clap wildly, shoving Paul onto the stage. The audience quiets for a moment, taking in his costume, until the music starts, violins and cellos... Paul opens his mouth to sing, but the crowd immediately ignores him, beginning to chatter amongst themselves. Paul begins to sweat as the music continues to play. Braddon and Hydrangea spur him on...

Go on! But the crowd are getting rowdy with themselves. Paul’s nerves are getting the better of him. The emcee stops the music. Starts it again. Braddon chews his thumbnail nervously as Paul begins to sing...

Vesti la giubba, e la faccia infarina. La gente page, e rider vuole qua. E se Arlecchin ti'invola Colombina, ridi, Pagliaccio, e ognun applaudira. No one’s listening. The the music swells and his voice rises above the crowd, not necessarily great, but far above average and very loud...

Tramuta in lazzi los spasmo ed il pianto in una smorfia il singhiozzo e ‘1 dolor, Ah! Conversations begin to tail off and people have no choice but to watch and listen to Paul. Braddon can’t believe hi ears...  32.
Bloody hell. -..as Paul launches into the aria.
Ridi, Pagliaccio, sul tuo amore infranto! Ridi del duol, che t'avvelena il cor! The song ends and the pub is deathly quiet... Paul realizes he’s made a complete fool of himself...

EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT As Paul exits the pub with a sulking Braddon and Hydrange and dozens of well-wishers who continue to congratulate Paul and clap him on the back. With a nudge from Hydrangea, Braddon half-heartedly congratulates Paul.
Well done, I suppose. I still reckon the fix was in.
There’s always Christmas.
(brightening) Bloody well right.
Congratulations.
Good night. They walk off with Braddon singing a scratchy “operatic” Good King Wenceslas. He puts his arm around Hydrangea, bu she shrugs it off. Paul smiles then pulls out an envelope revealing...

head_text.subj: A CHECK FOR THREE THOUSAND POUNDS

text: He allows himself a two-step jig before tucking the check back inside the envelope when suddenly...  33. He’s jerked roughly backwards by his collar and slammed down onto the pavement.
Well, if it isn’t everyone’s favorite circus freak. Hallo Potsy. He and another HOOLIGAN stand over Paul.
Get off me. He tries to stand, but Matthew kicks his ribs. Paul buckles.
What’ve we got here then? He snatches the envelope from Paul’s hand. Paul lunges fo it, but Matthew sidesteps and Paul’s face hits the curb.
Bloody hell, have a look at this.
(eying the check) What’s an obese clown doin’ with this kind of dosh?
Give it back. With surprising speed he finds his feet and SMASHES Matthew in the face with all his might... Matthew blinks, but appears otherwise unfazed. He holds u the check...
You’re gonna pay for that. He puts the check in his pocket and is about to lay into Paul when suddenly Braddon leaps onto his back, letting out a war cry--

May the Flame of Arveron sustain me! Matthew recovers his balance and struggles to free himsel from the clinging, scratching, screaming Braddon, finally dumping him on the pavement next to Paul, who has been held down by the Hooligan.  34.
Here. He tosses Matthew a brick. Matthew raises it over his head, about to smash Braddon, when it suddenly falls out of his hand as his face goes limp and he falls to the pavement revealing--
Standing behind him, wielding a cricket bat. HOOLIGAN (CONT’D) Where the hell’d you get that?
From me. The Hooligan turns to see a group of PARTYGOERS dressed i various sports costumes: football (aka soccer), rugby, cricket, etc.
She’s welcome to it as long as she likes.
Or we can use it for her. The Hooligan runs. Braddon and Paul help each other up.
All right?
Yeh. You?
(to Hydrangea) You saved us.
You’d have done the same for me. (handing the bat back) Thank you.
(on one knee) I am your servant.
You already were my servant.  35.

I was? I was! Yes mistress. Command me, mistress. I’m not worthy. May I lick your ankles please? Hydrangea rolls her eyes as Paul reaches into Matthew’s pocket and removes his check. Matthew’s eyes open.
(offers his hand) Truce?
(whispered) I’m gonna get you for this.
Why? Matthew doesn’t answer just stares balefully...

INT. JULZ’ PARENTS’ HOUSE - DAY As she watches a video on YouTube -- the infamous monkey who scratches his butt then smells his hand and falls out of his tree. She laughs to herself, then answers her RINGING mobile phone.
Hallo?
What’s so funny?
(her expression darkens) Who is this?
It’s Paul.
I knew a Paul once.
You're cross with me.  36.
Three weeks goes well past playing hard to get.
Paul stands on the sunny prow of a vaporetto (water taxi) talking on his mobile.
(actually worried) It's been nineteen days. And I was just following your instructions.
Instructions to what?
You said not to call you until I was settled in Venice. A white, basilica appears behind Paul as the vaporetto merges into the Grand Canal, revealing the splendor of Venice.
You’re joking?
Check your e-mail.

Hang on. She turns to her computer and opens an e-mail from Paul then scrolls through a series of PHOTOS detailing Paul’s last few weeks... Still in his clown-costume, face scraped but smiling with his check. Buying his first suitcase. Boarding an Al Italia plane. Arriving at the Opera School. In his room, smiling beside the window and the view of th city. And finally one taken moments ago aboard the vaporetto.
I don’t believe it.  37.
Can hardly believe it myself.
Tell me everything. A BARITONE SINGS A SUSTAINED NOTE...
A tall, GANGLY STUDENT pumps the sound from his lungs, eyes widening as he runs out of steam, but fighting to keep the note alive at the behest of SIGNORA FIORENTINO, their fierce istrutrice.

The school is brilliant. It’s in an old sixteenth century palazzo, which floods twice a day with the tide. Paul and the others stand in “Wellies” (galoshes) in a foot of water, singing their hearts out. Even the legs of the piano wear rubber boots.
Every morning starts off with four hours of intensive Italian.
As Paul, running late, runs up the first floor stairs... He slows a bit at the second floor... Walks the third... And limps up the fourth, stopping to gasp for air...
Affords a beautiful view of the city. Paul sits in the back row, drenched in sweat but conjugating verbs out lou with the rest of the class as the LINGUISTIC TEACHER points them out on the board...
Vado, vai, va, andiamo, andate, vanno.
Which I find comes quite easily. Paul reaches into his bag for a handkerchief, still speaking the verbs without looking at the board.
In the afternoons...  38.
Where Paul stands at a music stand before an ASST. CONDUCTOR who uses his violin to take Paul up and down th scales...
We learn to read music.
(singing) Do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-la-la... The Asst. Conductor repeats “la” bowing back and forth on the violin until Paul gets it right.
La-la-si-si-siiiiii. The Asst. Conductor winces at the last note.
Where Paul stands on stage wielding a long baton with padding on the end. GERHARDT, a blonde German student, faces him with a similar baton as a FIT PROFESSOR watches with the rest of the class...
Or practice stage combat.
E ora, con molta attenzione. (“And now, very carefully.”) Paul swings and knocks Gerhardt into the orchestra pit.
(moving to help him) I’m so sorry.
Where Paul’s back is to us as he does something to his face. The MAKEUP TEACHER enters, clapping her hands.
Ok, mi permetta di vedere voi. (“Okay, let me see you.”)

Or basic hair and makeup.  39. The students turn, revealing their faces, made-up for a scene from Madame Butterfly. Paul turns mournfully; he looks more like Clarabell the Clown than a Japanese warlord.
Which isn’t my strongest subject. Julz laughs as she scrolls down to a self-portrait photo of Paul, smiling through his disastrous makeup.
Is the food gorgeous?
Where Paul loads his tray up at the sumptuous buffet table...
Heavenly. Home made pastas. Soups. And the bread... Then turns to face the room, tables filled with chatterin students and teachers...

What about the people? Have you made loads of friends? He walks amongst them, spotting an empty chair next to ALESSANDRA, a pretty young Italian woman who smiles briefly at Paul before Gerhardt slips into the chair ahea of him.
Where Paul sits at the end of a table, eating alone.

Oh yes, loads. Everybody’s quite friendly. He hears laughter, but refuses to look up at a group of students, including Gerhardt, laughing at the amount of food on his plate before Alessandra scolds them..
Where Paul whispers into his cell phone.  40.
Julz walks her Cairn Terrier “Candy Floss” through the hills above the city.
Have you had a gondola ride yet?
As Paul steps onto a narrow gondola, loses his balance an pitches over the other side, headfirst into the canal.
Uh, no. Haven’t tried that yet.
And what about the city? Is it breathtaking? Paul comes to a stop and grows silent as he looks up, slightly awestruck, at Titian’s towering masterpiece, “Th Assumption of the Virgin”.
It is. Reveal him standing before the apse of the Basilica Santa Maria Gloriosa Dei Frari, the famous Gothic choir stalls and rood screen behind him.
Do you miss me? INT. PAUL’S SLEEPING CHAMBER - NIGHT Paul lies in bed, talking with the phone plugged into its charger.
Terribly.
Good.
Good night.
Good night.  41. He hangs up. Taking a moment to stare at Julz picture which he’s made the splash-screen on his phone.
As she and Paul are handed the libretto for La Bohéme as Signora Fiorentino explains that they will be...

...effettuare insieme l' apertura duetto di Mimi e Rodolfo. ("...perform together the opening duet between Rodolfo and Mimi.”) Allesandra smiles at him kindly, though clearly not thrilled. Paul only meets her eyes for a moment, then looks down, flushed and nervous. Gerhardt glowers in the background...
(singing as he reads) O soave fanciulla, o dolce visio di mite circonfusa alba lunar. In te vivo ravviso il sogno. Ch'io vorrei sempre sognar! Signora Fiorentino cuts him off--

Non, non, non... Okay, this is um, ‘ow you say, the spark... The moment of love creation. (speaks the words from memory ) O soave fanciulla, o dolce visio, Oh! Lovely girl, oh sweet face. In te vivo ravviso il sogno. Ch'io vorrei sempre sognar! I see you in a dream I will dream forever... Look at her, she is beautiful, non?
(without looking) Yes.  42.
Look. With your eyes. Paul looks at Allesandra, flushing again.
She’s very pretty.

(to Allessandra) E voi, guarda su di lui. (“And you, look at him.”) Paul offers a hopeful, broken-tooth smile. Her eyes widen at the sight of his teeth. She tries to cover, but he knows what he isn’t...
(CONT'D)
Egli 6 molto...eh... Ha un cuore puro, no? ("He is very...um... He has a pure heart, no?”) He looks down again...
(Italian accent...) Is okay.
Sorry, I... She takes his face in her hand and turns it so she can really see him. Finally, she smiles...
Buono. Dream only of each other... Allow all other thoughts to slip away. She begins to play again on the piano as we...
Paul emerges with his suitcase, reading from a guidebook to Lake Como when--
Paolo? She follows him out of the doorway.  43.
You are travel for the...fine settimana?
Oh, the weekend. Yes, I’m on my way to Lake Como.
Da soli? ("By yourself?”)
Si.
You want see Italia while you here?
As much as I can.

Where Paul stares out the window, watching the DUOMO slid past before they cross the Arno River towards the vineyar encrusted hills of Tuscany. Alessandra sits in the co-pilot seat, talking animatedly above the engine noise with her brother MANU. Paul snaps some pictures. Click. Click.... And on the final picture...

CANON FIRE, as TEN HORSES AND RIDERS, resplendent in a dazzling array of silks and colors, launch over a startin rope and begin racing around the square, which is filled with THOUSANDS OF SCREAMING SPECTATORS. Paul and Alessandra stand on a balcony overlooking the square, along with the rest of her obviously well-off FAMILY. The horses round a very sharp turn and thunder almost beneath the balcony.

They have race this race since sixteen hundred fifty-six. Two every year. One horse represent one, eh, neighborhood of Siena. My family live Chiocciola, the Snail. We have second most win, but Oca, the Goose have win the most times. The horses circle the square and head for them again. One of the jockeys shoves a competitor off his horse.
What do you get if you win? Di cosa hai vinto? She thinks a moment, then touches a fist to her chest.
Orgoglio.
Orgoglio? (shakes his head) Non capisco. Alessandra leans to her FATHER who turns and smiles at Paul...
Orgoglio means pride. His eyes linger on his daughter, who raises her chin in mock defiance before he kisses her.
Is your father not proud of you? Paul struggles to respond, then mercifully--

Qui vengono!. ("Here they come!”) As the horses appear once more and churn towards the finish line. Taking the sharp turn, one of the horses stumbles, tossing the jockey into the crowd which ROARS.. The rest of the horses cross the finish line and the family erupts into CHEERS!
Weeks of practice later, Paul and Alessandra sing the due together...

A! To sol commandi, amor! A! To sol commandi, amor! ("Ah! Love, you rule (“Ah! Love, you rule alone!”) alone!”) Fremon nell' anima, Oh! Come dolci scendono, ("Already I state in ("How sweet his spirit,”) praises,”) Le dolcezze estreme, Le sue lusinghe al core... ("the heights of (“enter my heart”) tenderness!”) Tu sol comandi amore! Nel bacio freme amor! ("Love, you alone ("Love trembles at our rule!) kiss!") An orchestra joins the soundtrack, supplanting the piano as the duet continues over the following MONTAGE:
Where Paul and Alessandra are on-stage with a director, who has Paul put his arm around Alessandra. Both are uncomfortable until Paul makes a face and she laughs.
Attenzione!
Where Paul and Alessandra sing in each others arms. The Asst. Conductor stops them, pushes them apart and has the hold hands.
Prova di nuovo. ("Try it again.”)
More verbs on the board. Paul sits in the back, eyes closed, right hand gently waving/conducting the music fro the scene which we hear on the soundtrack and he hears in his head.

Where Paul and Alessandra sit together, surrounded by other students but oblivious to all others as they discus a part of the libretto.  46. Unconsciously, she leans an arm on his shoulder as they argue over the same passage. The gesture is lost on Paul, but Gerhardt notices.
As Paul and Alessandra sing while holding hands, Signore Fiorentino places her hands on the small of their backs and pushes them together.
Molto meglio. ("Much better."”)
Alessandra is venting her frustration with all of the bac and-forth...
Apart. Together. Hold hand. No hold hands. What it matters so much?
Well sod them.
“Sod them?”
It means... Fino loro asini. ("Up their asses."; Alessandra nods in agreement) Che cosa volete fare? (“What do you want to do?”)
I don’ know.
The final performance... On stage, Paul and Alessandra perform the duet in costume with props and light makeup.
Dammi il braccio, mia piccina. ("Give me your arm, my dear.”)
Obbedisco, signore! ("Your servant, sir.”)  47. The fatal moment comes and Paul takes charge, grabbing he roughly around the waist and pulling her to him.
Che m'ami di’ "Tell me you love me.” ¥' His hand gently holds her face, turning it to him just as she had done with him... She almost laughs with joy.
Io t'amo! ("I love you.”)
Amore! Amor! Amor! Amore! Amor! Amor! (Behold! My love! My love!)
Where Paul and Allesandra run into the square, hopping an yelling and bouncing for joy.
Questo 6 stato incredible! ("That was incredible!”)
Siamo i campioni di Venezia! (“We are the champions of Venice!”)

Di tutto il mondo! (“Of the whole world!”) Allesandra leans in and kisses him. He’s stunned as she pulls away, a new expression on her face before she kisse him again, deeply. His eyes close for a brief moment, before he pulls away.
You are okay?
Yes, sorry I...
What is wrong?
Nothing, I just...
Li ha fatto l’amore, prima, si? (“You have made love before, yes?")
(beet red at the suggestion) Of course I have, but... Actually I haven't, but that’s not--
You have a friend-girl at home?
Um, well, yes. A girlfriend.
E lei il tuo primo? (“Is she your first one?”)
Lei 6 l'unico. (“She is my only one.”)
There is a difference.
There is.

Signore Fiorentino was right. You have a very pure heart. She kisses him firmly on the mouth then smiles at him. Sh turns quickly away and speed dials her cell phone as she walks down the square towards the Basilica.
Ciao, Papa. He watches for a moment, then walks the other way. Dials his own phone.
Where Roland watches “The Bill” while Yvonne snores softl on the couch beside him.
Yeah, hello?
Oh, um hi, Dad.  49.
(to Yvonne) Oy, it’s the eye-talian. (to Paul) What’s good, son?
Oh you know, lots of studying and singing.
(sarcastic) Sounds grand.
Actually we, my scene partner and I, we just won a scene competition and--
Hang on, yer mum’s on the snore again. (adjusts Yvonne's head) Tucked into the sherry again this evening. So did you win anymore pocket money?
No, but even better, they told us we get to sing for--
(listens) Well that’s not bad. He’s no Willie Nelson, mind you.
Right.
INT. JULZ’ PARENTS’ HOUSE - NIGHT (INTERCUT) Jaw dropping as she hears the news...
Sod off!
Paul sits on a stone wall, feet dangling over the edge as he watches the lights of the city shimmer over the waters
It’s true.  50.
You’re not takin’ the piss?
I swear I’m not.
I don’t believe it. Paul! What’re you going to sing?
The duet, I suppose.
Oh. Right. ‘Course you are.
And thinking of you the entire time.
There’s a good boy... Nervous?
Off the charts.
Maybe open with a joke or something, let the air out a bit.
A joke? In front of-- Have you gone mad?

Arguably the 20th century’s greatest tenor sitting in the first row, dabbing his upper lip with a scented handkerchief while listening to Alessandra sing an aria. Paul watches from the wings as her final note diminishes, applauding along with the audience. Pavarotti is on his feet, eyes devouring Alessandra as he claps. She feels hi ardor and smiles shyly. He beckons her to sit beside him as the Asst. Conductor brings him a teacup of hot water.
Maestro.  51.
Grazie. He follows Alessandra until she’s next to him, and begins whispering/congratulating her. In the wings, a pair of students stare at Paul.
I wouldn’t want to follow that.
Me neither.
Thanks. He sets his jaw and heads for the center-stage microphone

Good evening. (paralytic fear) It uh, must be bargain night, it only costs one tenner to get in, instead of the usual three...tenors. A smattering of laughter from the crowd. Pavarotti notice him for the first time, but seems less than amused. Paul begins to sing; Rodolfo’s, “Che Gelida Manina", the same aria Paul “conducted” in his room at his parents’ house. He’s singing well, better than we’ve ever heard, eyes tightly closed as he focuses on his breathing and pitch. Finally his eyes open...and what he sees seems to deflate his entire being, even as he continues to sing... HIS POV; where Pavarotti’s full gaze is on Alessandra, wh although flattered, tries to turn his attention to Paul, but to no avail. Finally, the aria ends to polite applause. Ignoring Paul completely, Pavarotti rises to leave until the Asst. Conductor whispers in his ear.

Ah, si. (turns to Paul; obviously hasn’t heard a word) You inhaled after in te, vivo ravviso il sogno. Rodolfo would not have run out of breath there.  52. Paul is about to speak, but Pavarotti’s back is to him an he’s heading for the door, arm in arm with Alessandra leaving Paul alone on stage, destroyed... Paul stands for a moment, then slowly turns and walks off as we...
Gray as ever. A bleak contrast from the vibrancy of Italy
I hates to say it, but I did warn you.
Where Paul and his parents are just finishing Sunday dinner. Paul stares at his plate.
Put a sock in it, Roland. At least he had the nerve to have a go.
Which has left him where?
Thanks, mum. That was lovely. He takes his plate to the sink.
There's treacle tart and strawberries.
I’ve got work in an hour. Kisses her goodbye.
When’s that lovely girl coming to visit again?
See you guys.
Oy. Hang on a second. He follows Paul out the front door.  53.
Paul works the combination lock to his bicycle which is chained to the iron railing at the base of the steps.
There’s an opening down the mill. The wait list’s a kilometer long, but, how'd you like to come work with me?
No thanks, dad.
It's time to grow up now, son. You've had your great adventure, which is more’n I ever had, but singing didn’t work out so--
I know, dad.
(grabs his arm) No you bloody well don’t! You think you’re too good to work the mill. Well I’ve got news for you, boy, you’re the one’s not good enough.
(after a beat...) I’ll be late. Roland lets him go. Paul pedals out onto the road.
Just what the world needs, more bloody mobile phones!
As Paul cycles stoically to work.
Where Paul rings up a sale for an ELDERLY COUPLE...
Right. Now how far away from the house will the telephone actually work?
As far as you'd like.  54.
Nonsense. The cord on our last telephone didn’t even reach to the back door.
But this hasn’t got a cord.
We don’t take kindly to bullshitters.
That's because you’re bloody insane. He walks away, despite their protestations. Braddon sees this and, after throwing a look at Paul, goes to help the elderly couple.
(shouting) Good afternoon! May I help you?!

Paul puts together a cardboard display stand. His phone buzzes. He sees Julz picture with a text message: “?” He taps it, revealing the “text thread"; a series of “?"” and “!" and “?12?!2?!2?!" stretching back over a week. He switches his phone off just as Braddon enters.
Not quite the pinnacle of customer service, I’d say.
Sorry.
Perhaps you’re confused...see you’re the diffident, jolly one, whilst I’m the edgy, mysterious bloke with bubbling cauldrons of danger and pizzazz.
Right.
It’s bad as all that is it? (off Paul’s look) Right... Come on. Pulls Paul to his feet.  55.
Where we going?
Desperate times call for naked dancers.

Where Paul and Braddon sit at the edge of the stage, framed between the legs of a gyrating dancer. Braddon’s smile is ear to ear as his head bobs and swivel to the music... Paul still looks miserable.
Braddon follows Paul out of the club where they unchain their bicycles from the pole holding up the marquee.
There you are. All better now?
(not at all...) Yes, loads. Thanks.
D'you know, I think I could headline there. The first step on my career to pop superstardom.
That's your dream is it?
When I was younger. Before x-box payments and chest hair and whatnot.
You haven’t got chest hair.
‘Course I do. Gallons of it... It’s just very blonde.
Right... And what about now?
Dreams? Honestly?  56.
If possible.
Be nice to have a family of my own. Oh and one day go to New Zealand. Hire a car and do the Lord of the Rings tour. See where the hobbits live.
That's it?
Well, yeah. The lower your expectations, I find, the greater your general level of happiness.
(agreeing) Right. They pedal off down the road...
Then again, a threesome wouldn’t be the worst thing that could happen.
Obviously. EXT. PAUL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT Paul hops off his bike and pushes it towards the entrance where Julz stands with several large suitcases.
Hi.
Hi.
How did you--?
Mum drove me. She waited as long as she could but...
Right. Um... Sorry, did we?
You stopped ringing me back.  57.
Yeah.
Playing hard to get again?
Just feeling sorry for myself.
Always flattering on a man.
He didn’t even know I was there.
(shrugs ) He’s a celebrity.
Sorry?
He may be a great singer, but anyone that famous can’t be anything but an ass of intergalactic proportions.
It’s lovely to see you.
Is it?
I’m an enormous idiot.
You are. And?
I’m truly sorry.
And?
I’m an ass of intergalactic proportions?
Well said. Lucky for you, I’ve decided to take you up on your offer.
You have?  58.
I have.
Em, which offer exactly?

Seeing as your self-esteem’s down the loo, and we’re never going to have a proper go at a relationship living so far apart, I decided to accept your offer to...move in together. To give it, you know, a proper go. Nothing ventured...
Nothing gained.
So...? Paul stares dumbfounded... Realizes she’s hanging herself out there for him...
Oh right! Yes, of course. That would be, um...
What?
Wonderful.
(smiling) And?
I’m an ass of intergalactic proportions.
Yes, though there’s still hope for you. He reaches down to carry one of her suitcases but can’t even lift it off the ground.
I packed a few things.
We may need a bigger flat.
An immense seawall jutting out into the gray water. Surfers and wind surfers brave the cold waters alongside as Paul and Julz walk hand in hand.
So, maybe the joke wasn’t the best idea.
He was so goggly-eyed over Alessandra, I could’ve pulled me trousers down and he wouldn’t’ve noticed.
That beautiful was she?
Oh yes. Very. (realizing) But in that Italian sort of way; all dark and... Not my type at all.
Mmmm. It’s not the end of the world, you know. There are loads of other operas. They reach the end of the wall and sit, legs dangling ove the waves.
Not for me. I went to Italy to... Somewhere in there I got a bit outside myself. Just because I won some silly competition, I started to think... Anyway, I’ve got my expectations well back in line.
Ridiculous.
Really, I’m done with singing.
So you say.
I’m serious, Julz.
I believe you, darling, but I know better...  60.
Oh do you?
The first time we ever chatted on-line. Do you remember how you introduced yourself?
As Paul, I imagine.
You said you were a singer.
It was more impressive than saying I worked in the produce department at Tescos.
I don’t care where you work. I care that you're happy, and that you’ll always love me back.
(she just said she loves me...) I will, you know.
Good. (standing) Besides, as I recall, you promised you’d sing for me.
“Someday.”
Someday when?
(singing) I love you as you love me, in the evening and the morning,
A small, stone church at the heart of Llangynwydd, an ancient hilltop village, one of the oldest Christian settlements in all of Wales.  61.
Nor was there a day when you and I did not share our troubles. Guests arrive in suits and dresses, picking their way across the grassy cemetery which surrounds the church wit eroded headstones.
The chapel is nearly full of FRIENDS AND FAMILY. Paul stands alone before the altar.

And when we shared them, they became easier to bear; Everyone stands as Julz appears, resplendent in a white dress with veil, escorted by her FATHER. Paul sees her and begins to choke up. She smiles at him, telling him he’s going to be fine...

You comforted me in my distress, and I wept in your laments. Julz reaches the front, kisses her father after he lifts her veil and stands to face Paul before the altar. The VICAR gives his benediction and they exchange rings.. Paul finally loses his composure and Julz kisses him to pull him out of it.
Therefore, may God’s blessing be upon you.
Where Paul sings the English translation of Beethoven’s Ich Liebe Dich (I Love You) to Julz before everyone.
You, my life’s joy. God protect you, keep you for me, and protect and keep us both. Now it’s Julz turn to cry. He kisses her as everyone stands and applauds, many people wiping their eyes.

(through tears) So you can sing after all.  62. Braddon is a disaster as rivers of tears stream from both eyes. He turns to hug Hydrangea who bears him up for a moment, before reaching back and removing his hand from her ass.
Paul and Julz whirl and twirl at the center of the cramme dance floor. Finally, the song ends...
D’you want a drink?
Champagne please.
Back in a flash, Mrs. Potts.
Why thank you, Mr. Potts. He weaves through the crowd to the bar where Roland is holding court with a coterie of his friends from the mill
Hello, Dad.

(far from sober) Paul, you remember Charlie and Bill from down the mill. (he and Bill share a laugh at the rhyme) And this here’s Matthew, the new chap. Paul stops as he sees Matthew, his nemesis grinning coldl at him. Matthew offers his hand.
Paul and I went to school together. Felicitations an’ all that.
(tentative) Thanks.
Maybe you'll sing us a pretty song as well? The others laugh hysterically.  63.
Maybe you’1l get knocked out by a girl again. Matthew goes cold. He’d love to take a swing at Paul but knows better. Instead, he just smirks portentously until Paul turns away from them.
(to the bartender) A champagne and a lager, please.
Matthew’s only joking, Paul.
How could you invite him?
I paid for half this bender, I can invite who I like. Besides, he’s a good lad, and a hard worker. The implication being that Paul is not.
(getting his drinks) Thank you.
What’s wrong with Matthew? They’re interrupted by Paul’s former Choirmaster (from th opening montage).
I say, young man. I don’t know where you found it, but your vocal control has improved by light years.
Thanks very much, sir. I was in Italy for a while, but I don’t really sing--
I’m commissioned to conduct a production of Aida in Bath. And you, sir, would make a wonderful Radames.
Really?  64.
No no, he’s all finished with that nonsense. He’1ll be getting an honest job, earning an honest wage.
There’s no pay, I’m afraid.
I’ll take it.
Bloody hell.
As the door handle turns, then flips back to its original position... After a beat, it turns again, finally opening as Paul and Julz, she in his arms, spill into the room...
No, no, on the bed. I couldn’t stand another second in these torture devices. He deposits her on the bed and helps her remove her shoes to her great relief.
Oh, that’s lovely. I shall never dance again.
Famous last words.
Reminds me of someone I just married.
The lead tenor in Aida. I still can’t believe it.
This is the best wedding day ever... Which reminds me. She jumps to her feet and opens a cabinet, revealing a beautiful antique gramophone and a mylar bag which she hands to Paul.
What's this?  65.
I got sparklies-- (flashes her rings) --this makes it even.
Not unless you'll be paying this off for the next ten years.
Open it. He removes a thin sleeve bearing a photo of--
Puccini.
That’s an original recording from the premiere at... (grabs a slip of paper) ...-La Scala, Milan on April twenty-fifth--
Nineteen twenty six. Conducted by Toscanini himself, but how--
E-bay, how else? She places the disc on the gramophone and sets the needle... The tenor, Miguel Fleta, begins to sing...
Nessun Dorma.
This was recorded before Pavarotti was even born. She sits on the bed next to him and kisses him as the ari unfolds...
What is he saying?
Nessun dorma. None shall sleep. Calaf has been rejected by the woman he loves, a princess. Kisses him again as she starts removing her dress.  66.
What’s it always have to be a princess? Why can’t checkout girls have great love stories written about them? (re: her dress) Give us a hand.
If she can guess his name by dawn, she gets to call off the wedding and chop his head off.
I like that bit.

(translating) -.-my secret is hidden within me. None will know my name. On your mouth I will say it when the light shines. She removes her undergarments and stands before him, naked. PAUL (CONT’D) And my kiss will dissolve the silence that makes you mine.
So kiss me.
I’ve never done this before. She nods, knowingly, then helps him remove his shirt.
So what happens to them?
Well, she tortures all of his friends who refuse to reveal his name, but when dawn comes, he kisses her and she falls--
--madly in love with him. She pulls him down onto the bed as we linger on the gramophone and... FADE TO BLACK.  67.

Where an impressive Egyptian temple backdrops the stage filled with PERFORMERS in ancient Egyptian and Ethiopian costumes. Paul appears at the center of the company, carrying his own with great gusto. The Choirmaster conducts the orchestra, very pleased with what he hears. A pastiche of music from the opera plays over...
Paul hangs a poster for the opera in the front window, indicating two weeks until the premiere. Welcomes a CUSTOMER with a smile and spring in his step and begins discussing various phone options.
Paul rides his bicycle home, arms spread wide as he belts out a soaring high C5 note. A passing car honks in reply.
Where they sit over dinner, talking happily. She says something flirty and he dives over the table to kiss her, not a trace of shyness.
Paul sings the aria Celeste Aida. A DIRECTOR offers him some stage direction, which Paul executes beautifully. At the end, he takes a deep breath, scratches his side.
Paul makes another attempt at stage makeup, but he’s stil hopelessly crap.
Where Paul and the other leads sing into microphones as the Choirmaster and DIRECTOR huddle with an ENGINEER.
Paul leaves through the Artists’ Entrance, laughing with his fellow performers. He passes a flyer taped to a streetlight pole: “Two Days To Premiere.”  68.
Paul enters the empty store.
Hallo? Brad? He hears sniffling in the back. Passes through the curtai to--
--find Braddon, dressed in full elfish wizard regalia taking slugs from a bottle of bright green alcohol in between chest-heaving sobs.
What’s happened?
It’s over. I’m finished with the lot of it.
Your ears are coming off?
What? Oh. Off Paul’s gesture, he pulls his half-hanging, pointy elvish ears off and throws them in the trash.
Shall I leave you alone?

So there I am, right in the heart of Morgol Forest, having blasted my way through an army of Hobgoblins using a spectacular array of spellcraft. When whom do I see with her tongue down the throat of some bloody hippogriff?
Oh no.
As if unicorns and hippogriffs could ever be together. You can look it up, it’s genetically impossible!
I believe you.  69.
(offering the bottle) Creme de Menthe?
The show opens tomorrow.
Rejected again.
All right. Just a nip then. He takes a small swig, wincing as it goes down, holds his hand to his side which burns...
Julz enters, wearing her pharmacy uniform.
Hal-oo? Radames? Wherefor art thou? She sets some shopping bags down on the tiny kitchen counter. Sees the television’s on, so he must be home...
Paul? Suddenly, Paul emerges from the bathroom, doubled over an clutching his side in enormous pain...
Oh my god.
Something's wrong.

location: PRINCESS OF WALES HOSPITAL, EMERGENCY ROOM

text: The doors fly open as a team of EMS workers wheel Paul in on a gurney with Julz following nervously behind them. Dr. Thorpe is almost completely gray.
What’ve we got? (recognizes Paul) What, you again?  70.
Bloody Creme de Menthe.
Lower abdominal pain. Fever. Nausea.
Appendix. Triage two, please. (to Paul) You might qualify for our frequent flier membership.

location: PRINCESS OF WALES HOSPITAL, WAITING ROOM

text: Where Julz waits with Yvonne as Dr. Thorpe enters.
Well, the good news is, it’s got nothing to do with the Creme de Menthe.
And the not good news?
As Dr. Thorpe flips on a lightboard, revealing an x-ray o Paul’s abdomen.
The appendix hasn’t ruptured, yet.
Thank god.
Yes definitely, although it’1l have to come out I’m afraid.
When?
How’s four o’clock suit you?
I can’t.
His opera opens tomorrow night.
Oh, fantastic. Which one?  71.
Aida.
Oh, is that the Madonna one? Wonderful performance that. I’m afraid singing’s quite out of the question.
I’m the lead. They’re counting on me.

An appendectomy is invasive surgery. If we leave it in it’s sure to rupture and he could die. Take it out and any great effort, like singing for instance, you’re liable to burst the stitches and cause irreparable damage to the kidneys or diaphragm.
How irreparable?
It's possible that singing...wouldn’t be possible.
Well, that’s that then. Paul and Julz exchange looks.
Lit up with banners and posters displaying the names of the cast including Paul.
Where Paul warms up his vocal chords while bathing them i the output from a clothing steamer.
Neeee, nayyyy, nahhhh, noooo, nuuuu. (up an octave) Neeee, nayyyy, nahhhh, noooo, nuuuu. He removes his shirt revealing an enormous post-surgical bandage across his stomach.  72.
As Julz, Yvonne and Roland take their seats.
It’s right stupid, if you ask me.
Do shut up, Roland. The least we can do is support him, no matter how insufferably daft he’s being.
I’1l thank you both not to talk about my husband that way.
Yes, you’re right, dear. It’s just so-- Really, why can’t he just put himself first for a change?
Because then he'd be just like everyone else. And he’s not is he?
(kisses her cheek) You’re a very lovely girl. She takes Julz’ hands in hers...

(rolling his eyes) I’d trade both me ears for a pint about now. Despite his bluster, he’s just as nervous as they are. Th Choirmaster takes his place in the orchestra pit and the lights go down and the Prelude begins to play... The trio watch nervously as... Paul appears on-stage, resplendent in the costume of an Egyptian military commander. He sings his opening lines, discussion with RAMFIS, the high priest.
His first aria’s right at the top. Ramfis exits the stage and Paul steps forward... The TRANSLATION CRAWL appears on-screen, above the stage.  73.

Celeste Aida, forma divina. Heavenly Aida, divine form. Mistico serto di luce e Mystical garland of light fior. Del mio pensiero tu and flowers. You are queen sei regina. Tu di mia vita of my thoughts. You are the sei lo splendor. splendor of my life. Julz mouths the words with him, squeezing the life out of Yvonne’s hands...

He’s doing it. He’s all right. They clutch each other, while Roland stares transfixed at the stage in utter disbelief. He looks around at others i the audience to see if they’re equally stunned then is physically moved as Paul hits a powerful high note.
Paul comes off stage during the transition, hands on his stomach and wincing in pain as he waits beside a stagehand.
Y’‘ okay?
Yeah, fine.
Sounds bloody marvelous.
(appreciative but hurting) Thanks.
Scene II is underway, the PRIESTS and PRIESTESSES of the temple pray to the spirit Phtha... And then something seems wrong. A priest repeats his line...
What’s wrong? One of the other priests steps up and sings Paul’s line.
That’s supposed to be-- (then she’s up) Excuse me please.  74. Pushing her way through to the aisle, then running out to the lobby.
Julz runs around to the Artists’ Entrance where an ambulance is just pulling up.
Oh God. Paul emerges, tunic soaked with blood from his broken stitches, arms around the shoulders of the Stagehand and BACKGROUND PLAYER as the EMS WORKERS take him.
(seeing Julz) I’m okay. I’m okay. Yvonne arrives, followed by Roland who carries a lager in a paper bag as Paul’s loaded into the ambulance.
What did I tell ya?
Where Paul lies unconscious as a team of SURGEONS operate on him.
Paul sleeps with Julz curled around him. She whispers as she strokes his hair.

They found tumors on your adrenal glands. I know you’re frightened, and not singing again is more than you can bear, but I just want you to know that if you never sing again, I'll do everything in my power to fill that void with as much happiness as I can possibly manage. She closes her eyes and holds him tighter.
EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - DAY As Julz’ car pulls up and she runs around, opening the passenger side door for Paul, who looks uncomfortable and miserable.
You sure you don’t want to wait in the car? Paul shakes his head. Whispers that he has to go to the loo, even talking clearly hurts...
That you can do on your own. INT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - DAY As Paul enters to an uproarious--
The entire opera company is there along with his Yvonne and Braddon. They all begin to sing, opera-style...
For he’s a jolly good fellow. For he’s a jolly good fellow. For he’s a jolly good fell-ow! Which nobody can deny!
(“auditioning”) Can de-nyyyyyyyyyy- Ends in a coughing fit. Paul is touched and perplexed as the Choirmaster steps forward.

For bravery and the rather thick-headed willingness to sacrifice himself for his fellow man, and woman, and those undecided... Bath Opera is proud to present you with the first Golden Appendix award, in hopes for a clean bill of health, and a speedy return to the stage.
Hip-hip.
Hooray!  76.
Hip-hip.
Hooray! Paul accepts the Golden Appendix award, an amorphous lump of clay painted gold, and starts to speak softly.
What’s that? Speak up then. He smiles bashfully then leads into Julz ear, whispering.

You've no idea how much this means to me. My whole life I never even had one true friend, much less an entire company. From the bottom of my heart, thank you. And much as I'd love to continue talking through my wife, you'll all be very upset with me if I don’t use the loo immediately. Everybody cheers as he hustles quickly off towards the back. Drinks are ordered and the Choirmaster hugs Julz.
So how's he doing?
He’s heartbroken, of course. Time will tell.
(hand her a cassette) This’ll guarantee he can have his voice back whenever he likes.

Paul looks in the mirror as he checks the fresh bandages around his mid-section, poking and prodding them. So far, so good. He licks his lips and, building his determination, tries to hum a single note but nearly collapses in pain. He hears the front door open...
Hal-oo? I've got some lovely vichyssoise.  77. He hurriedly buttons his shirt, but not in time...

Freeze, Jack! (he drops his hands) How many times--? Would you enjoy an infection then? Perhaps another surgery, like Dr. Thorpe warned you about? (he hangs his head; pouting) Didn't think so. Help me with me groceries. He kisses her cheek then takes several plastic shopping bags off her hands and carries them into the kitchen.
Paul helps a seven year-old GIRL and her MUM program her first mobile phone. He’s lost several stone of weight and his hair’s shorter indicating the passage of some time...
Or you might like the dancing frog ringtone, which is quite popular.
What kind of an idiot wants a dancing frog on their phone? Suddenly, a DANCING FROG ringtone is heard. Braddon runs from the back and answers his flashing phone.
(suddenly black...) Yeah? What up B-Dog. For reals? Yo, that’s off the chain, yo, yo.
(to the girl) Excellent point.
Much love. Mad respect. Peace out.
I didn’t know you were a rapper.
Oh, that’s just my boss up at HQ in Croydon. He’s mah boyy.  78.
You don’t look African.
The outside may be vanilla darlin’, but the inside’s chocolate through and through.
Have you got a large penis? Braddon’s about to respond, but a murderous look from the girl’s mum freezes his tongue.
Paul comes in to find Braddon doing a pathetic breakdance celebration.
What’s got you all chuffed up?
I just got a raise.
That’s fantastic, well done. (surprised...) If you don’t mind me asking, um, why exactly?
What d’you mean, why? I’m a stupendous Manager. I feel a sudden urge to sing.
Oh, please don’t. Actually, no offense or anything, and this is no reflection on my feelings towards you personally, but you’re actually kind of a crap manager, if you really look at it.
Well you that, and I know that, but... If you must know, our little shop had the highest sales in all of Wales over the last two quarters. (singing) The highest sales in all of Waaaaaaaales!
That’s wonderful! (realizes...) (MORE)
You mean over the six months since I got back from surgery?
Yes, but--
During which time I actually kept the shop open between the hours of ten and six?
Well yes but--
And put my singing on hold because--
Because you’re a sissy.
(ignoring him) And put the ads in all the local papers? And--
Alright, blimey. You’re getting a raise as well.
I am?
Couple’a quid an hour.
You serious?
(singing again) The highest sales in--
--all of WAAAAAAAAAALES! So powerful Braddon takes an inadvertent step back and trips over an unopened box. He glares up at Paul from the
Bastard!  80.
(stunned) I can sing.
These cost me ten pound down the--
I can sing! I can--
Don’t!
(whispering at first) The highest sales in-- (belting it out)

Braddon goes down again... INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT BUILDING, LOBBY - DAY Where Julz removes the mail from the postbox, and flips through as she heads for the stairs. Suddenly she stops a a letter and tears it open, reading hungrily.
Dear Mrs. Potts we are in receipt of your cassette...and would very much like to...
As Paul, strapping on his bicycle helmet, answers his mobile phone.
Julz?
You'll never guess what-- You'll never guess what--
You first.
I can sing.  81.
I know.
No, I can sing. Now. Again.
Oh, thank god.
Paul coasts out of the parking lot on his bicycle, pumpin his fists in the air.
Promise you won't be cross with me.
Cross is the last thing I’m going be with you when I get home.
You don’t know the half of it.
Various shots of Paul singing “The Highest Sales in All o Wales” with both fists thrust in the air as he pedals through the rolling hills with their ancient stone walls.
What’ve you done, Julz?
Do you remember the cast recording of Aida, before it opened?
Julie-Ann?
Well, I made some copies of it and sent them ‘round to a few agents in London.
You what?
Someone had to do something to get you off your bum.
But, what if it turned out I couldn’t sing?  82.
Remember when I first met your mum and dad and told them what a wonderful singer you were.
Load of bollocks as far as you knew at the time.
I believed in you... And it turns out I’m not the only one. You’ve got an appointment tomorrow in London with a music agent who thinks you’re quite good.
You’re joking.
I’m not.
Paul WIPES FRAME, riding away from us down a mountain road, whooping as he goes until--

head_text.subj: AND SMASHES INTO HIM HEAD ON--
PAUL IS THROWN FROM HIS BIKE, BOUNCES OFF THE WINDSHIELD,
OVER THE HOOD AND LANDS ON THE PAVEMENT A DOZEN YARDS

text: Where Julz is seen walking angrily/terrified towards the entrance.

location: PRINCESS OF WALES HOSPITAL, EMERGENCY ROOM

text: She walks up to the nurses’ station.
(stammering) I’m um... My husband, Paul... There was an accident?  83.
Hallo, Julz. Right this way... You know we're thinking of building you two your own entrance. He sees she’s only barely holding it together. Puts his arm around her and leads her into--

Where Paul lies encased in a plaster cast that covers his upper torso and left arm which juts out in front of him a a right angle, supported by a metal pole. His face is cut and stitched in several places and supported by a thick neck brace.
His collar bone’s shattered and he’s got severe whiplash.
But he’s not--
He won’t be running a marathon anytime soon, but he’s not in any great danger.
(slightly drugged) Hello, Cameron.
(kissing Paul’s face) You have got to stop doing this to me.
I was singing again.
Go to sleep. FADE TO BLACK.

Where a radio plays a commercial for BRITAIN’S GOT TALENT “searching for the next singing, dancing or other talent sensation” and a hundred thousand pounds to the winner.  84. The ad is followed by Andrea Bocelli’s rendition of Con t Partiro. Paul reaches out and switches the station to Coldplay. He’s reclining on an orthopedic chair while surfing the internet for debt consolidation information. He’s gained weight again and his hair is unkempt. The doorbell rings and he hoists himself to his feet with a grunt, and shuffles his way over to the door which he opens to reveal Braddon.
Are you Paul Potts?
No.
Perfect, then you’re just the man I’m looking for. Paul lets him in.
What you been doing?
(looking around) More than you I’d say. Christ, how much moping can one man do?
I’m not moping. I’m just...
Not doing anything... Like working.
I told you, I’m still not up to-- Braddon tosses Paul a Car Phone Warehouse “Manager” name tag and a set of keys.
Too late.
What's this?
Feast your eyes upon the South Western District Sub-Manager for Carphone Warehouse.  85.
You are not!
Paul shuffles along beside Braddon as they walk along the road outside the mill and its towers of belching steam.
What’d you do, cook the books again?
I’m quite capable of honest advancement, thank you very much.
Somebody died?
The former South Western District Sub- Manager. Cholera. On safari or something. Anyway, I start Monday in Croydon.
(fumbling with the keys) Honestly, I don’t really think I’m up to it.
Bollocks. You’re on disability for over a year, they’ve cut up most of your credit cards and poor Julz--
Do you have any idea how many pills I have to take every day? I didn’t choose this!
Believe that life is worth living, and your belief will help create the fact.
What?
Henry James...or Mighty Mouse, I’m not sure which. They arrive at Braddon’s new/used motorcycle, barely standing what with the various cases and bags strapped to it at all angles...  86.
You’re leaving now?
Commerce waits for no man. Gonna miss you, laddie. You’re me best mate. There, I said it.
Rubbish. Uber-district-sub-under-managers don’t have time for such emotions.
It's District Sub-Manager, and I'll be poppin’ round every now and again to check up on ya. Make sure there’s no funny business goin’ on.
You couldn’t spot funny business if it was tattooed to your eye-lids.
You know that, and I know that, but--
Give us a ring when you’re settled.
I’m told the women in Croydon shag like wild ferrets.
Might want to think about a rabies shot. (Braddon considers this before they hug) Thanks, Brad.
Give the missus a good squeeze for me.
No, but I’1l1 tell her you said bye. Braddon kicks-starts the motorcycle which ROARS powerfull to life...
May the-- ...then stalls immediately. He tries to start it again...
May the-- Crap. May the--  87.
Bit more clutch, maybe. Braddon scoffs until the bike roars to life.
May the-- The bike suddenly jerks forwards, zooming him out of earshot.
--flame of Arveron sustain you. He watches Braddon’s motorbike teeter away down the road, before turning and shuffling back home.

Looking in through the windows as the lights come on inside. Paul walks to the window, looking up at the gray Welsh sky that’s reflected in the glass and on his face a he pulls the chain on the neon “OPEN” sign.
He turns to face the store which is, predictably, in shambles.
As Julz waits patiently at the front door as Paul locks up.
Good first day?
(unenthusiastically) Yeah. Brilliant. She walks slowly as he shuffles along the arcade of shops
Any luck with the hiring?

(distracted) Only a few applicants. Be better once we get an ad going in the paper.  88. She follows his eyes as they linger on a display in the music store window, a life-size stand up of Palacido Domingo, promoting a new album. She takes his hand as he looks away, sensing her pity but not wanting to talk about it...
How was your day?
Where Paul and Julz sit over baskets of skate & chips wit Yvonne and Roland.
...pressure caused a the number five furnace to literally split down the side.
Oh my lord.
Bunch’a the molten steel got out. Eighteen hundred Celsius, damn near melted half the machinery before we got the fire out.
Was anyone hurt?
Billy Watkins almost got incinerated, but lucky for him Paul’s friend Matthew managed to hoist him out of the pit before the soup got ‘im.
He’s not my friend.
He’s a bloody hero.
Good for him.
(diverting...) Anything exciting down at the shop?  89.
Hang on, love. (to Paul) What ever disagreements you had when you were in school, don’t you think it’s time you--
Disagreements? Do you see that, Dad? He shows him a scar starting just at the edge of his hairline.
That's from a bicycle chain, wrapped around his fist while two of his droogs held me down. I was twelve.
I don’t remember that happening.
What was it you told me, dad? Maybe if I lost a few stone, I wouldn’t provoke them.
Look just because you’ve had a run of bad luck... You’ve had plenty of opportunities to sort yourself out.
(not backing down) All those years wasted on that singing nonsense.
You’re not singing now, are you?
Roland.
You’re wife’s working two jobs to pay your hospital bills and all you do is mope about.
He’s back at Car Phone Warehouse.
Oh, well, that’s a step in no direction, isn’t it. (MORE)

We may not have a lot in common, but you’re my son and I’ve never been prouder of you than when I heard you perform in Bath. That was heroic. You want to give it up, anyone would understand after what you've been through...but you haven’t have you. You’re afraid to sing, but you’re afraid to move past it. That’s not life. Julz and Yvonne stare at their hands, trying to hide thei agreement...
