Paul sits at the computer, pouting while working on their pitiful finances while Julz watches Coronation Street on ITv.
Three hundred pounds paid, another thirty- seven thousand to go.
We'll be all right.
How do you know.
It's just money, isn’t it. As long as we’ve got each other.
And Coronation Street.
Well, yeah. Paul turns back this his computer as a series of pop-up advertisements appear.
Bloody pop-ups. He closes several of them, then stops on the last, an ad for Britain’s Got Talent.
(attention on the TV) What’s that darling?  gl.
Nothing, just... There’s this new contest. A hundred-thousand quid to the best performer in Britain.
Robbie Williams’1l win that for sure.
It's for amateurs.
Too bad you don’t sing. You’d’ve won it laughing. Paul stares at the window then minimizes it... After a moment, he brings it back up on the screen and starts entering his details...
It’s cheaper than a lottery ticket.
Are you seriously giving it a go?
You’re right. I’m such a plonker.
No, do it!
It's stupid. He moves to close the window when--
Heads or tails?
Ay?
(with a 50p coin) Heads you forget all about it, tails you push send.
Julz.
I was at work today, chatting with my girls, who asked after you as they do now and again. And do you know what I said?  92.
That I’m a tiger in bed?
Aside from that... I said I can’t really say how my husband is, because, to be completely honest, I can’t remember the last time he laughed.
(after a beat) Maybe my dad’s right.
Sod your dad. What do you want? Paul takes this in...
Heads. Julz flips the coin...
Where Paul lies on his side, Julz nuzzled up behind him a he’s lost in thought...
What?

I was just thinking... It would be nice to sing for an audience again. I think I could let it go after that. He looks over at the bedside table where the 50p coin sits, showing the profile head of Queen Elizabeth II.
Probably won’t even get an audition anyway.
(drifting into sleep...) Mmmmmm.

Where the 50p coin reflects the sliver of sunlight into Paul’s closed eyes, which snap open.  93. He frowns at the coin and jostles the bedside table, trying to shift it out of the sunlight. The coin doesn’t move. Paul reaches out for his clock-radio and tries to use it to shove the coin aside and instead ends up knocking everything off the table, waking Julz.
What’s happening!?
Sorry.
Where Paul looks over a job application. He’s smartened u and has the shop back in order.

Right, so where you answered “maybe” to the question, “Have you completed secondary school?” would you care to elaborate on that? A PUNK GIRL, with a huge pink mohawk and numerous piercings both in her face and her leather jacket, stares at him vacantly.
Not really, no.
Right. (as the phone rings) Just a second. Car Phone Warehouse. This is Paul speaking.
Where Julz is taking off her coat.
Is this Paul Potts the singer?
I’m a bit busy now, darling.
Oh right. Too busy to come with me to Cardiff on Friday.
Cardiff, what’s in--  94. As Julz hits play on their answer-phone. The voice of a FEMALE PRODUCER is heard.

Yes, Mister Potts. Is that right? Paul Potts. Oh my. Sorry, I’m calling from Britain’s Got Talent. We’ve received your application and .mp3 audition and-- Paul listens as he watches the Punk Girl remove a safety pin from her nostril... He turns away.
(as the message ends...) Well?
Um, brilliant.
What?
This Friday?
That’s what the lady said.
That’s not nearly enough time.
Well, that’s all the time you’ve got. See you at seven. Paul hangs up, terrified. He turns to see the Punk Girl i using the safety pin to pick at a large scab on her forearm.
Start Friday? The Punk Girl looks up, surprised.

INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT BUILDING, STAIRCASE - DAY Where we hear Paul long before we finally see him, huffin and puffing and sweating his way up the stairs until he collapses in a heap halfway up the final steps.

The largest city in Wales is seen in the distance as Julz drives Paul and Yvonne. INT. JULZ’ CAR - DAY Where Yvonne sits in the back seat reading over materials regarding the show, including photos of the judges, AMAND HOLDEN, PIERS MORGAN, and SIMON COWELL.
Right, so these are the judges. (sees Simon smiling) Now he looks like a very warm fellow. It says here, the auditions are going to broadcast live on ITV. Did you know that Paul?
(blanching) You’re joking?
(suddenly nervous for him) Shouldn't you be rehearsing or something?
I can’t. No telling what shape my vocal cords are in after so long. Better to just warm up properly then see what comes out rather than risk overdoing it now.
Right... But then how will you know if you sound any good?
Trust me, babe. At best it’1l be crap.
As long as you’re confident. He smiles nervously, staring out the window as the terror builds...
Where THOUSANDS have queued up outside the building, hoping for a walk-on audition. The queue seems endless as they drive past...
Are you meant to wait in that line?  96.
I think maybe this was a bad idea.
(putting her hand on his) They liked Paul’s song so much, he doesn’t have to audition. Paul watches the faces blur past as his apprehension grows...
Where Paul and the ladies are escorted through a swarm of people by a harried PRODUCTION ASSISTANT brandishing a clipboard and walkie-talkie.
--complete cock-up I’m afraid. All of a sudden Simon “has” to be on a plane to Dubai at three so everything’s been bumped up.
Just as long as I’ve got time to warm up.
How long do you need?
Twenty minutes should be plenty.
Take away ten minutes from that and you're perfect.
You mean I’m on in--
S’actually about nine and a half minutes, yeh? (handing passes to Julz and Yvonne) These should get you seats in the reserve section. Right through there. (to Paul) You're with me.
(turns to Julz) This was a mistake.  97.
You can warm up in ten minutes, can’t you?
Nine and a half.
We really must get--
(to Julz) It’s been proven I’m not good enough. Let’s just go home and--
Good enough for who? Bloomin’ Pavarotti? If you want a final go on-stage, then here’s your chance. Or, if you really want to have a go at being a professional singer, here’s your chance.
(into her walkie) We may have a problem. (to Paul) Nine minutes, yes or no.
Eight forty-five, actually. (off their looks) Sorry.
What would Toscanini do?
Where the Production Assistant leads Paul to the wings.
Just wait here for the pre-interview.
Pre-interview?

Who are you? Why’re you here? Just take a few minutes. Back in a sec.  98. She hustles off leaving him standing amidst several other performers: a MICHAEL JACKSON wanna-be, a JUGGLER and a WOMAN with a HOWLING TERRIER. Paul realizes he’s not in Kansas anymore and starts to warm up, just as a CAMERA CREW barrels in along with the hosts ANT and DEC who are fed background by the Productio Assistant.
(CONT'D)
--works at Car Phone Warehouse. He’s married. Teeth are all bashed up and sings opera.
Opera?
Paul, this is Ant and Dec. Three minutes. The camera light comes on and blinds him.
Where a YOUNG GIRL over-performs “It's a Hard Knock Life” on-stage. Julz and Yvonne are led to their seats, high in the nose-bleed section.
This is the reserve section?

(screaming into the phone) I don’t know if there’s a delay, just get your puckered old bum to a telly, do you hear me?! (hangs up; to Julz) Honestly! If he weren’t such an exquisite lover, I’d have to leave the man.
Paul stares nervously through a gap in the curtain at the myriad cameras and the enormous crowd as the imposing judges: PIERS, AMANDA and SIMON critique the contestant before him, a YOUNG GIRL.

That was absolutely excruciating. It was like a little kitten had been trapped in a box and was shrieking for its mum to come rescue it... Only mum’s too busy plugging her ears, isn’t she?  99. The young girl walks off the stage, failing to hold back her tears.
Julz and Yvonne sit way in the back.
He isn’t very nice at all.
I think Paul’s next. The lights come down as an image of Paul appears, projected on a screen.

For the next contestant, the world of showbiz seems a million miles away. It’s Paul. A mobile phone salesman from South Wales. We Paul watches the young girl lets out a huge SOB as she runs to her MOTHER.
(to Paul) I wouldn’t want to follow that.
Thanks.
(on-screen) By day, I sell mobile phones. Paul walks away from the Stage Manager, trying not to hyperventilate as he passes behind a pair of PRODUCERS.
Who’s this chap?
Joke contestant. The chubby opera fellah.
Oh, he’1ll be good for a laugh. Paul hangs his head. Finally, the truth of it...
(in the interview) By day, I sell mobile phones. (MORE)
My dream was to spend my life doing what I was born to do. He sighs, giving up once and for all...
Paul is seen on the screen.
Confidence...is...has always been sort of a difficult thing for me... I always find it a little difficult to be completely confident in myself.
Oh dear. She starts texting furiously into her phone.
The Stage Manager runs up to Paul...
You’re on. Motions for him to take the stage, but Paul doesn’t move, his eyes find the exit door.
Paul Potts everyone.
Julz sends the text then prays to everything she can thin of. The audience begins to murmur. Julz senses his hesitation...
Paul’s checks his buzzing phone... Reads the text from Julz: NOTHING VENTURED, NOTHING GAINED. PS. PAVAROTTI’S AN ASSHOLE. LOVE CAMERON. Paul smiles...  101.
(as a mantra) One foot, then the other. And then Paul steps self-consciously onto the stage, walk to the microphone, not looking at anything, keeping his teeth hidden...
Good afternoon. I’m Paul. Several thousand PEOPLE look on from the audience. His entire physicality seems to apologize for being there.
What are you here for today, Paul?
To sing opera. Simon and Piers exchange an “oh crap” look. The audience murmurs, this is going to be terrible. Paul tries to ignore them.

(annoyed) Okay. Ready when you are. The opening strains of Nessun Dorma begin. Simon leans back and sighs, putting his pen in his mouth, wishing Pau were back in Wales. Paul stares at a point above the audience until he finds Julz, which allows him to shut everything else out...
Nessun dorma. Nessun dorma. Simon looks up, chews his pen, suddenly interested as Pau begins the first crescendo...
Ma il mui mistero e chiuso in me. Suddenly the audience cheers. Julz and Yvonne react, clutching each other again... Amanda takes a deep breath, stunned as are Simon and Piers.

Il nome mui nessun spara, No no. Dilegua, o notte! Tramontate, stelle! Tromontate stelle! All'alba vincero!  102. Simon’s mouth hangs open. Amanda actually begins to cry a the audience rises to it’s feet.

Vincero. Vincero! The audience are on their feet, roaring... Julz and Yvonn hug each other, bouncing up and down... Even Simon applauds and smiles as the music ends... He looks back at the thundering audience, and actually laugh out loud. Paul takes a deep breath, happy to be finished then just stares at the floor, face tight, expecting the worst.
So you work at Car Phone Warehouse and you did that. I wasn’t expecting that.
No, neither was I.
This was a complete breath of fresh air. I thought you were absolutely fantastic. Paul smiles, somewhere between relief and vomiting.
You have an incredible voice. I think, if you keep singing like that, you are going to be one of the favorites to win this competition.

Paul nods and smiles shyly at the congratulations from SHOW STAFF and other CONTESTANTS. He heads out the back door just as Julz runs up to embrace him... He hugs her and begins to sob, burying his face in her neck as his entire body is wracked with spasms as the pai of the last three years flows from him in tears of joy.
It’s all right. It’s all right.

The grimy after-work men watch silently as Paul sings on each of the several televisions. As he begins the final high note, the men erupt into laughter, clapping Roland on the back as tears run down his face. Matthew watches, hating Paul all over again because he’s brave enough to be different. The First Drunk from the beginning leans over to Roland.
Bloody wonderful that. Matthew stands behind Roland, talking with several of the other men.
What kind of poof sings opera? Roland turns to face him.
Not exactly a chip off the old block, is he?
A bicycle chain?
What?
Is it true?
Um, well, we were only kids. Roland snarls and levels Matthew with haymaker. Matthew goes down, out cold.
Get this pile’a dung outta my sight. Two men pick up Matthew and carry him to the door, passin Paul, Julz and Yvonne as they enter. A cheer goes up as they’re recognized.
Paul and Roland stand outside, waiting for their wives.  104.
I want to tell you something... I haven't been the best... Chokes up. Paul puts his hand on his shoulder...
Dad, you don’t have to--
Shut up. (deep breath) The only real measure of a father’s success is by how far his children end up surpassing him in life. I’m not good with words...but you should be very, very proud of yourself.
Orgoglio.
What?
Nothing.
He’s standing back stage in a new tuxedo.
Nervous?
Always. Think I should open with a joke?
Probably not. Yeah, probably not.
If this ended tonight, I’d still love you forever.
D’you wanna make a run for it?
Up to you.  105.
Best not. See what happens. Julz kisses him and puts something in his hand.
For luck. Paul looks down to see the 50p coin and the face of Queen Elizabeth II.

head_text.subj: THE ACTUAL FACE OF QUEEN ELIZABETH II

text: Sitting beside the DUKE OF EDINBURGH in the royal box as Simon, Amanda and Piers are on-stage.

Now, of course, that was Paul Potts who went on to become the deserving winner of the whole competition. Since then, his first album has already sold over two million copies and he’s been number one in fifteen different countries. Ladies and gentlemen, I’m very proud to introduce Paul Potts.

A flute plays as an enormous video screen shows images of Paul’s audition and subsequent victory in the finals of Britain’s Got Talent. The screen rises and Paul walks out on stage alongside an entire orchestra and begins to sing... Paul’s nervousness gradually subsides and he looks out at the crowd, seeing the Queen and, several rows behind her, Braddon standing with a very pretty GOTH WOMAN. Braddon smiles and makes a ferret face, nodding over at the woman Paul smiles and continues the song as the CAMERA ORBITS around him, revealing him singing: At the Sydney Opera House...  106.
PAUL'S DEBUT ALBUM “ONE CHANCE” OPENED AT NUMBER ONE, OUTSELLING THE REST OF THE TOP-TEN COMBINED. On the Oprah Winfrey Show...
